p: Our results were in line with previous findings that a small number of amino acid substitutions can lead to different levels of temperature-dependent attenuation. Indeed, it has been shown that a single amino acid change occurring in WNV NS4B (C102S) resulted in restricted replication in Vero cells at 41Â°C and a highly attenuated phenotype in vivo [ 32]. In addition, another report described a mutation in the C-terminus of WNV NS4B (E249G) which attenuated the virus as manifested by smaller plaques, lower growth kinetics and lower RNA synthesis in vitro as well as causing lower morbidity and mortality in vivo [ 33]. While WNV NS4B is a few amino acids longer than BgV NS4B (255 vs 247 amino acids, respectively), in silico analysis suggest that the two mutations (WNV E249G and BgV N244K) occur at the same position when compared in an alignment (see Fig 3C). This confirmed that single mutations in distinct residues of NS4B can be instrumental for viral replication, whether it is temperature-dependent or not. Moreover, it was shown that changes in a conserved PEPE motif just prior to the NS4A/2K cleavage site (see Fig 3C) led to drastically impaired WNV replication and virion production [ 34]. The BgV NS4A C-terminal sequence does not include this conserved motif, which could play a role in its host-restriction and in the advent of the compensatory NS4A mutation observed.
